title: Sharing Schedule Generator
card_summary: A program that automatically generates sharing schedules which are used to share club events to different Facebook groups. It is currently being used as a marketing tool for UBC BizTech, UBC's largest tech club.
modal_summary: While working as a marketing director for UBC BizTech, I noticed that the creation of our event sharing schedules is a very tedious and repetitive task. As a result, I decided to build a Java program that generates these schedules automatically, directly coding our marketing strategy and scheduling algorithm into the program. I single handily wrote this 1500+ line program using Java for the algorithms and WindowBuilder for the GUI.
learnings: How to code in Java
Basic data structures and algorithms
How to create a GUI using WindowBuilder
Project planning

title: Gomoku Online
card_summary: An online multiplayer port of the classic 2-player board game: Gomoku, built using React.js, Node.js, Express.js and Socket.io. Designed to help connect people during the COVID-19 pandemic.
modal_summary: Growing up, one of my favourite board games was Gomoku. I have lots of fond memories playing against family and friends in this simple yet satisfying game. After the COVID-19 pandemic hit in 2020, I really began to feel the isolation from my friends and family. Inspired to combat this physical distance in my social circles, I decided to create an online version of Gomoku, allowing me to play against my family and friends no matter where they are located.
learnings: How to develop a full stack web game
Leveraging Socket.io to enable real-time, live interactions between players
Creating rooms each having their own state, allowing users to join and play in their own rooms
Building individualized connections, allowing the backend to send custom information to each player

title: Food Baby
card_summary: A webapp that utilizes the Google Vision API to help pregnant women easily identify the impact of certain foods during pregnancy. This project won the “Best Use of Google Cloud” award at Cmd-f 2021.
modal_summary: For the to-be-moms and expecting around the world, managing diet and knowing what is healthy can be stressful to manage. Our webapp is designed to make the lives of expecting moms a little easier, by helping them quickly identify foods that are good or harmful to their baby. Working in a team of 4, I spearheaded our back-end development by integrating our webapp with Google Cloud’s Machine Learning Vision API and Google Firebase. This enabled the direct identification and classification of foods from a single photo, a key feature of our webapp.  I also assisted the front-end development of several app pages using React and Bootstrap. This project won the “Best Use of Google Cloud” award out of 250+ hackers and 80+ teams at the Cmd-f 2021 Hackathon.
learnings: How to use the Google Vision API in a webapp
How to use Google Firebase
How to handle the pressure and succeed in ideating, planning, and delivering a fully functional webapp under 24 hours
How to effectively communicate with team members under pressure and a tight deadline

title: Online Management Platform
card_summary: A management web-app for a stock analysis service. Features include: adding and removing stock insights, publishing articles, managing user comments, and viewing user statistics.
modal_summary: In summer of 2019, I received the opportunity to collaborate on the creation of a management web-app for a Chinese stock analysis service with over 900 monthly users. I was responsible for writing 80% of all back-end code, where I used PHP and SQL queries to connect front-end inputs to back-end data changes in our MySQL database.
learnings: How to write complex SQL queries
Basic PHP
Basic MySQL operations

title: Just a 2D Game
card_summary: This game may seem like a simple platformer on first sight, but it has several hidden tricks and puzzles built in for the player to explore. It’s the first Unity game I’ve created and it’s currently published on Itch.io.
modal_summary: Over the summer of 2018, I built a small 2D puzzle platformer game using the Unity game engine. I coded and designed all aspects of the game using C#, some basic pixel art, and lots of YouTube tutorials. It was definitely a great learning experience about the Unity engine and the game development process in general.
learnings: How to create moveable characters in Unity
How to use a tiling system in Unity
How to use particle effects in Unity
Basic C#
Basic level design

title: AFK (Away From Keyboard)
card_summary: AFK is a chrome extension that allows users to navigate web pages through their voice. This project was in the top 35 out of 145 project submissions for nwHacks 2020, winning our team the “Wolfram Award”.
modal_summary: Working in a team of 5, I was responsible for implementing the auto-scroll feature, which enabled a webpage to scroll down when the user reads the last words on screen out loud. I implemented this feature using a text-scraping function written in JavaScript. Additionally, I also implemented a toggle button, allowing the user to turn voice recognition on/off inside the extension popup. Other commands of our extension include: “go down/up”, “open/close tab”, “go back/forward”, and “reload/refresh”. This project placed within the top 35 spots out of 750+ hackers, 175+ teams and 145 project submissions at nwHacks 2020, winning our team the “Wolfram Award”.
learnings: How to create a Chrome Extension
Basic JavaScript
Using JavaScript to trigger browser and web page actions
Don't give up even if you have to switch ideas halfway into the 24-hour hackathon :')

title: Schedule Assigner
card_summary: Works as an add-on to my “Sharing Schedule Generator” project. Takes a list of names and a sharing schedule in the form of .txt files, then outputs an assigned schedule showing who should share in what group and when.
modal_summary: This was my final project for the CPSC 210: Software Construction Course I took at UBC. Although I have built software prior to the course, I learned how to truly design programs instead of just piecing code together after CPSC 210. This project was a learning experience on how to design, test, and write cohesive code to create truly robust programs. I used Java to write the algorithms, JavaFX to build the GUI, and tested my code using JUnit.
learnings: Object-oriented design principles (Single Responsibility Principle, Liskov Substitution Principle)
Writing robust programs and throwing exceptions
Testing my code using JUnit
How to build a GUI using JavaFX

title: GitHub Issues Viewer
card_summary: A simple web app that utilizes the GitHub API to fetch and display a list of issues from any GitHub repository. Users can further filter the fetched issues by their status: “open”, “closed”, or “pull-request”.
modal_summary: Originally the creation of this web-app was tasked to me as an interview assignment for a company I applied to. After completing the initial requirements, I decided to take this project further and put my own spin on things and add some additional design / features that were not required in the original outline. With permission from the company, I’m able to showcase this new re-vamped version of the web-app.
learnings: How to create a dynamic web-app using React and Bootstrap
How to utilize GitHub API in an application
Using CSS to build a responsive design
Better organization of CSS stylesheets

title: Mental Health Webapp
card_summary: Designed for mental health help seekers and counsellors, our app acts as a one-stop-shop for one’s mental health resources, whether that be hotlines, resource centres, or even to search and book appointments.
modal_summary: Working in a team of 3, we built a mental health networking and help web-app dedicated to those seeking and offering help. Within the project, I built 11 out of our total 17 webpages, each page is a PHP file that acts as both the front-end and sends SQL queries to the backend. I also worked with my teammates to design the database by creating an ER diagram, project schemas and listing any functional dependencies.
learnings: Full-stack web development with PHP, HTML, CSS and MySQL
Database design
Creating ER diagrams
Writing database schemas and functional dependencies

title: Designed Websites
card_summary: From 2016-2018 I ran a small web-design business: ITReliable. Working as the web designer, I created websites for clients using WordPress and managed them using cPanel and phpMyAdmin.
modal_summary: While working as a web designer for ITReliable, I was able to create websites for all kinds of clients including renovators, restaurants, and accountants. I also provided technical support and customer service for our clients, ensuring that they are satisfied with their website. Eventually I stopped using WordPress to create websites and taught myself JavaScript, HTML, CSS and React to create more dynamic websites like this site!
learnings: Web design
Webpage management
Domain management
IT troubleshooting
